lead_paragraph: Zainab is a cadet at the female Officer Candidate School called Malalai Company at the Kabul Military Training Center, roughly eight miles east of the capital. She sat on her bed at the female barracks on a recent day being comforted by two other female cadets. She said she did not feel well because two days before, her fiancé had threatened her with knife and told her he would kill her if she did not leave the Army.

snippet: To the Editor:    I was quite disturbed that the Ms. Foundation is not sponsoring a more gender-neutral day such as "Take Our    Children    to Work Day." If, as the article stated, by the end of the century "two of every three new workers are exp...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was quite disturbed that the Ms. Foundation is not sponsoring a more gender-neutral day such as "Take Our Children to Work Day." If, as the article stated, by the end of the century "two of every three new workers are expected to be female," there is a reason. Employment in our economy has completely shifted over the past 20 years from manufacturing or goods to service. This means that traditionally female jobs such as secretary, teaching, social work and nursing are going to be the overwhelming majority of the jobs available. If we do not begin to teach our sons as well as our daughters that these jobs are worthwhile, many of our sons will not be working come the turn of the century. PATRICK O'BRIEN Brooklyn, April7 The author is a social worker.

headline.main: From the Library: Don't Tread on Us

abstract: City of Chivilcoy, Argentina, opts to ban beauty pageants from its municipal festivals, responding to high rates of eating disorders and dangerous beauty procedures stemming from cultural obsession with beauty; move has won praise from women's rights groups and even some former pageant contestants.

Employment in our economy has completely shifted over the past 20 years from manufacturing or goods to service. This means that traditionally female jobs such as secretary, teaching, social work and nursing are going to be the overwhelming majority of the jobs available. If we do not begin to teach our sons as well as our daughters that these jobs are worthwhile, many of our sons will not be working come the turn of the century. abstract: Catherine Rampell It's the Economy column laments just a quarter of all Americans in computer-related occupations are women; notes this may be public-image problem, since many women do not often come into contact with computer scientists and engineers and do not understand what they do; argues imbalance could be addressed if a television show portrayed women working in the field.

abstract: Chinese school officials place more male teachers in classrooms in campaign to instill traditional masculine gender roles in boys; move is response to anxiety in country where boys outnumber girls but lag behind them academically; critics say effort is sexist and evidence students benefit from having same-sex teachers is scarce.

snippet: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to make it easier for women who have children to continue careers, rather than leaving the work force....

abstract: Japanese Prime Min Shinzo Abe has pledged to make it easier for women with children to continue working; promise is part of his broader effort to reinvigorate economy, which is struggling with twin problems of shrinking population and smaller labor force; Abe has focused on support for child care, which is in short supply, but his policies face added challenge of changing entrenched corporate culture that has been unfriendly to working mothers.

headline.main: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
